subject: Law
title: The Voting Rights Act of 1965
description: A quick win: understand The Voting Rights Act of 1965.

hook.text: Literacy tests, poll taxes, and violence kept Black Americans from voting. One law changed that overnight.

buildup.text: The Voting Rights Act of 1965 banned discriminatory voting practices and authorized federal oversight of elections.

discovery.text: Section 5 required states with histories of discrimination to get federal approval before changing voting rules.

twist.text: Shelby County v. Holder (2013) gutted Section 5, calling its formula outdated. States quickly passed new restrictions.

climax.text: Voter ID laws, polling place closures, and gerrymandering have since become major battlegrounds.

punchline.text: The right to vote was hard-won. Protecting it is a permanent job.

quiz.question: What did Shelby County v. Holder do to the Voting Rights Act?
options: Struck down the preclearance formula in Section 5
